summary.long: Song Of Solomon is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The Most Beautiful Song by Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let him kiss me over and over again!
    Your love is better than wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fragrance of your perfumed oil is wonderful.
    Your name is perfume poured out.
        Therefore the young women love you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take me with you! Let’s run away!
    Let the king bring me into his private chambers.
The daughters of Jerusalem will rejoice and be happy for you.
    We will value your love more than wine.
        They love you appropriately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The daughters of Jerusalem, I’m dark and lovely
    like the tents of Kedar,
        like the curtains of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t stare at me because I’m dark;
    the sun has tanned me.
My mother’s sons were angry with me.
    They made me the caretaker of the vineyards,
        but I didn’t take care of my own vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tell me, you whom I love,
    where do you graze your flock?
        Where do you make your flock lie down at noon?
Why should I be considered a veiled woman
    beside the flocks of your companions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you don’t know, most beautiful of women,
    go out after the flock and graze your young goats beside the shepherd’s tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My darling, I compare you to a mare
    among Pharaoh’s chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your cheeks are lovely with ornaments,
    your neck with strings of jewels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We will make ornaments of gold for you,
    accented with silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While the king was sitting at his table,
    my perfume sent forth its fragrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is to me a pouch of myrrh
    that lies between my breasts all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms
    in the vineyards of En-gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at you! You are beautiful, my darling.
    Look at you! You are so beautiful.
        Your eyes are doves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at you! You are handsome, my beloved, truly lovely.
    How lush is our couch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The beams of our house are cedar,
    our rafters are pine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’m a flower from Sharon,
a lily of the valleys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a lily among thorns,
    so is my darling among the young women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like an apple tree among the trees of the forest,
    so is my beloved among the young men.
In his shade I take delight and sit down,
    and his fruit is sweet to my taste.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has brought me to the banquet hall,
    and his banner over me is love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sustain me with raisin cakes,
    refresh me with apples,
        for I’m weak with love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I wish that his left hand were under my head,
    and that his right hand were embracing me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Swear to me, young women of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles or by the does of the field,
that you won’t awaken or arouse love
    before its proper time!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The voice of my beloved!
Look! He’s coming,
    leaping over the mountains,
        bounding over the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is like a gazelle or a young stag.
Look, there he stands behind our wall,
    looking through the windows,
        gazing through the lattice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved spoke to me:
    “Get up, my darling, my beautiful one, and come on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! Winter is past.
    The rain is over and gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blossoms have appeared in the land.
    The season of songbirds has arrived,
        and cooing of turtledoves is heard in our land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fig tree has produced its fruit,
    the grapevines have blossomed and exude their fragrance. 
“Get up, my darling, my beautiful one, and come on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My dove, in the hidden places of the rocks,
    in the secret places of the cliffs,
show me your form, and let me hear your voice.
    For your voice is pleasant,
        and your shape is lovely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Catch the foxes for us,
    the little foxes that destroy the vineyards,
        our vineyards that are in bloom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved belongs to me and I belong to him.
    He is the one who shepherds his flock among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Until the day breaks and the shadows flee,
    turn around, my beloved,
and be like a gazelle or a young stag
    on the rugged mountains.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll get up and go all around the city,
    throughout the streets, and in the squares.
I’ll seek the one I love.
    I sought him, but didn’t find him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchmen who go all around the city found me.
    I asked, “Have you seen the one I love?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I had just passed them
    when I found the one I love.
I held him and wouldn’t let him go
    until I brought him to my mother’s house,
        to the room of the one who conceived me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Swear to me, young women of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles or by the does of the field,
that you won’t awaken or arouse love
    before its proper time!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is this coming up from the desert
    like columns of smoke,
perfumed with myrrh and incense
    from all the fragrant powders of the merchant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! It’s Solomon’s sedan chair,
    with 60 of the best soldiers in Israel surrounding it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All of them are wearing swords and are
    experienced in battle.
Each has his sword on his thigh,
    ready for the terror of the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
King Solomon made the sedan chair for himself
    from the trees of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made its posts of silver,
    its back of gold.
Its seat was purple,
    and its interior was lovingly inlaid
        by the young women of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come out, young women of Zion,
    and see King Solomon with the crown
with which his mother crowned him
    on his wedding day—
        his day of great delight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at you! You are beautiful, my darling.
Look at you! You are so beautiful.
Your eyes behind your veil are doves,
    your hair is like a flock of goats
        coming down from Mt. Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your teeth are like a flock of sheep about to be sheared,
    who are coming up from being washed.
All of them are twins,
    not one has lost her young.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your lips are like a scarlet thread,
    and your mouth is lovely.
Behind your veil,
    your temple is like a slice of pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your neck is like the tower of David,
    built with rows of stones.
A thousand shields are hung upon it,
    all the shields of the warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
    twins of a gazelle grazing among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Until the day breaks and the shadows flee,
    I’ll go to the mountain of myrrh
        and to the hill of frankincense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My darling, you are altogether beautiful
    and there is no blemish in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
You have made my heart beat faster, my sister, my bride.
    You have made my heart beat faster
        with one glance of your eyes,
    with one strand of your necklace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful is your love, my sister, my bride.
    How much better is your love than wine,
and the fragrance of your perfume
    than all kinds of spices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your lips drip honey, my bride;
    milk and honey are under your tongue.
The scent of your garments
    is like the fragrance of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My sister, my bride, is a locked garden
    a locked rock garden, a sealed up spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your shoots are an orchard of pomegranates,
    with choice fruit, henna with nard,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
nard and saffron,
    calamus and cinnamon,
with all the trees of frankincense,
    along with myrrh and aloes, and all the finest spices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are a garden spring,
    a well of fresh water,
        streams flowing from Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Awake, north wind, and come, south wind.
    Make my garden breathe out,
        let its fragrance flow.
Let my beloved come into his garden,
    and let him eat its choicest fruits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ve come into my garden, my sister, my bride;
I’ve gathered my myrrh with my spices.
I’ve eaten my honeycomb with my honey.
I’ve drunk my wine with my milk. 
Eat, friends!
    Drink and become drunk with love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was asleep, but my heart was awake.
    There’s a sound! My beloved is knocking.
“Open up for me, my sister, my darling,
    my dove, my perfect one.
For my head is drenched with dew,
    my hair with the dampness of the night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I’ve taken off my clothes—
    am I supposed to put them on again?
I’ve washed my feet—
    am I supposed to get them dirty again?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved reached out his hand for the latch.
    My feelings for him were aroused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I got up to open the door,
    and my hands dripped with myrrh,
my fingers with liquid myrrh,
    on the handle of the lock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I opened the door for my beloved,
    but my beloved had turned away; he was gone!
My very life went out when he departed.
    I searched for him,
        but couldn’t find him.
    I called out to him,
        but he didn’t answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchmen making their rounds
    through the city found me.
They beat me, they bruised me.
    Those guarding the walls took my cloak from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I charge you, young women of Jerusalem,
    “If you find my beloved, what are you to tell him?
        Tell him that I’m weak with love.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is so special about your beloved,
    most beautiful of women?
What is so special about your beloved,
    that you charge us like this?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is dazzling,
    with a dark and healthy complexion,
        outstanding among ten thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His head is pure gold,
    his hair is wavy, black like a raven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His eyes are like doves
    by streams of water,
bathed in milk,
    mounted like jewels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His cheeks are like beds of spices,
    like towers of perfume.
His lips are lilies,
    dripping with liquid myrrh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His hands are rods of gold,
    set with beryl.
His stomach is carved ivory,
    inlaid with sapphires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His legs are pillars of marble
    set on bases of pure gold.
His appearance is like Lebanon,
    choice like its cedars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His mouth is sweetness,
    and all of him is desirable.
This is my beloved, this is my friend,
    young women of Jerusalem!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where did your beloved go,
most beautiful of women?
Where did your beloved turn,
so we may look for him with you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved has gone down to his garden,
    to the beds of spices,
to graze his flock in the gardens
    and gather lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I belong to my beloved, and my beloved belongs to me.
    He is the one who grazes his flock among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are beautiful, my darling, like Tirzah,
    lovely like Jerusalem,
        as awesome as an army with banners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn your eyes from me,
    for they excite me.
Your hair is like a flock of goats
    coming down from Mt. Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your teeth are like a flock of ewes
    coming up from being washed.
All of them are twins,
    not one has lost her young.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your temple behind your veil
    is like a slice of pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are sixty queens and eighty mistresses,
    and too many young women to count,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but my dove, my perfect one, is unique.
She’s unique to her mother,
    she’s pure to the one who gave birth to her.
Young women see her and call her blessed,
    queens and mistresses praise her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is this who appears like the dawn,
    beautiful as the moon,
bright as the sun,
    awesome as an army with banners?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I went down to the walnut orchard,
    to look at the green sprouts in the valley,
to see whether the vine had budded,
    whether the pomegranates had blossomed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Before I knew it, I imagined myself
    among the chariots of my noble people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Return, return, Shulammite,
    return, return, so we may look at you!
Why should you look at the Shulammite,
    like you watch the dance of the two camps?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful are your feet in sandals,
noble lady.
The curves of your thighs are like ornaments,
    the work of a skilled artist’s hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your navel is a rounded goblet
    that never lacks mixed wine.
Your abdomen is a bundle of wheat,
    enclosed by lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
    twins of a gazelle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your neck is like a tower of ivory.
    Your eyes are like the pools in Heshbon,
        beside the gate of Beth-rabbim.
Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon,
    which faces Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your head crowns you like Mount Carmel.
    Your flowing locks are like purple,
        and a king could be captured in the dangling tresses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful and lovely you are,
    you are love with its exquisite delights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your stature is like a palm tree,
    and your breasts are like clusters of fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I told myself, “I’ll go up the palm tree,
    and take hold of its fruit.
May your breasts be like clusters of the vine,
    and the smell of your breath like apples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May your mouth be like good wine.
May it go down smoothly to my beloved,
    gliding gently over the lips of the sleeping ones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I belong to my beloved,
    and his desire is for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come, my beloved.
    Let us go out to the country,
        let us spend the night in the villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let us go early to the vineyards,
    let us see whether the vine has budded,
whether the blossom has opened,
    whether the pomegranates have bloomed.
        There I’ll give you my love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The mandrakes give off their fragrance,
    and over our doors are all the choice fruits,
both old and new,
    that I’ve stored up for you, my beloved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If only you were like a brother to me,
like one who nursed at my mother’s breasts.
If I found you outside I would kiss you,
and no one would view me with contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would lead you,
    I would bring you
to the house of my mother
    who used to teach me.
I would give you some spiced wine to drink,
    from the juice of my pomegranates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let his left hand be under my head,
    and let his right hand embrace me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Swear to me, young women of Jerusalem,
    that you won’t awaken or arouse love
        before its proper time!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is this coming up from the desert,
    leaning on her beloved?
Under the apple tree I awakened you.
    There your mother had gone into labor with you;
        there she went into labor and gave birth to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Set me like a seal over your heart,
    like a seal on your arm.
For love is as strong as death,
    passion as intense as Sheol.
The flames of love are flames of fire,
    a blaze that comes from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mighty bodies of water cannot extinguish love,
    rivers cannot put it out.
If a man were to give all the wealth of his house for love,
    he would surely be viewed with contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have a little sister,
    and she has not yet reached maturity.
What will we do for our sister
    to prepare her for her engagement?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If she’s a wall,
    on her we will build a battlement of silver.
If she’s a door,
    we will enclose her with planks of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was a wall and my breasts were like towers.
    Then I became like one who finds peace in his eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Solomon has a vineyard in Baal-hamon.
    He entrusted the vineyard to caretakers—
each one is to bring 1,000 pieces of silver
    in exchange for its fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My vineyard belongs to me and is at my disposal.
    The 1,000 are for you, Solomon,
        and 200 are for those who take care of its fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who sit in the gardens,
    companions are listening for your voice,
        but let me hear it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come quickly, my beloved, and be like a gazelle
    or a young stag on the mountains of spices.
verses.speaker: Narrator
